G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:

G.L. c. 209B, \u00a7 10.proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition is extremely general—that the complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw. Mason v. Coleman is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court decision squarely addressing family-law issues (removal/relocation, joint custody, best interests standard, G.L. c. 208 § 30), and it is authoritative Massachusetts family-law precedent. Even without knowing the rest of the complaint, citing Mason v. Coleman as part of relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw is accurate and appropriate.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 30, governs removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents where one of the parents seeks to relocate without the consent of the other parent. Removal of the children may be authorized by the court only “upon cause shown,” meaning a showing that removal is in the children’s best interests. Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). In Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), we addressed removal where one parent had sole physical custody of the children. Today we consider the appropriate standard where parents have joint physical and legal custody.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition is extremely general: that the complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw. Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas is a leading Massachusetts family law decision on custody and removal, articulating the "real advantage" standard and interpreting G.L. c. 208, §§ 30, 31, within the best-interests framework. It is therefore clearly relevant Massachusetts family law caselaw and appropriately cited for that broad proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these “best interests” are to be determined.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition is extremely general: that the complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw. Rolde is a Massachusetts Appeals Court family-law decision addressing divorce, property division under G.L. c. 208, § 34, custody, and visitation standards. It discusses and applies Massachusetts family-law principles and cites multiple Massachusetts family-law precedents, so using it as part of a set of relevant Massachusetts family-law authorities is accurate and supported by the opinion.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: Consistent with the mandate of G. L. c 208, § 34, the Probate Court judge “made detailed findings on each item in the statutory collocation.” Bahceli v. Bahceli, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 446, 449 (1980). Bianco v. Bianco, 371 Mass. 420, 423 (1976). Rice v. Rice, 372 Mass. at 401. Putnam v. Putnam, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 10, 16-17 (1977). Newman v. Newman, 11 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (1981). It is well settled that a judgment awarding alimony or a division of marital property which is supported by findings necessary to sustain it will not be set aside unless those findings are “plainly wrong.” King v. King, 373 Mass. 37, 40 (1977). Angelone v. Angelone, supra at 729.

Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361 (2011).proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361 (2011).support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is extremely general: that the complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw. The excerpted portion of Adams v. Adams does not set out or discuss substantive Massachusetts family law principles; it focuses narrowly on appellate impoundment procedure and S.J.C. Rule 1:15. While Adams is a Massachusetts family law case overall, this cited text does not itself provide authority for any specific family law rule, so it does not substantively support the broad proposition stated.
Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361 (2011).relevant_excerpt: "The clerk of this court then properly carried the impoundment forward on appeal, and the case file was closed from public inspection. See S.J.C. Rule 1:15, § 2 (b), as appearing in 401 Mass. 1301 (1988)... Perhaps the rule should be changed to require one who has obtained an impoundment order in the trial court to apply anew to the appellate court for impoundment of the appeal."

Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 134.raw_text: Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 134 (2010)
Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 134.proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 134.case_name: Massachusetts Nurses Ass'n v. Commonwealth Employment Relations Board
Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 134.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw. Katzman v. Healy is an employment/labor law case involving public-sector labor relations, union activity, and Massachusetts General Laws c. 150E; it does not concern family law issues such as divorce, custody, support, or domestic relations. Therefore, this decision does not provide authority for a proposition about Massachusetts family law or related caselaw.
Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 134.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff, Massachusetts Nurses Association (union), filed a prohibited practice charge against the employer, Taunton State Hospital (hospital), with the Commonwealth Employment Relations Board (board) alleging that the hospital committed a prohibited labor practice when it ordered hospital workers to remove their union logo-emblazoned T-shirts.... The board acknowledges that, generally, the wearing of union insignia constitutes lawful, concerted activity protected by G. L. c. 150E, § 10(a)(1)."

Baccanti v. Morton, 434 Mass. 787 (2001).proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Baccanti v. Morton, 434 Mass. 787 (2001).support_reasoning: The proposition is extremely general: that the complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw. Baccanti v. Morton is a leading Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court decision on division of marital property under G.L. c. 208, § 34, including treatment of premarital assets and unvested stock options. It is therefore clearly relevant Massachusetts family law authority for property division in divorce, so citing it in a family-law complaint is substantively appropriate.
Baccanti v. Morton, 434 Mass. 787 (2001).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 34, provides that a judge “may assign to either husband or wife all or any part of the estate of the other.” That includes property acquired prior to the marriage. … [T]he language in the statute that a party’s “estate” includes “all vested and nonvested benefits, rights and funds” clearly indicates that both vested and unvested stock options may be treated as marital assets.

Zucco v. Zucco, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 593 (2.raw_text: Zucco v. Zucco, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 593 (2012)
Zucco v. Zucco, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 593 (2.proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Zucco v. Zucco, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 593 (2.case_name: Superior Mechanical Plumbing & Heating, Inc. v. Insurance of the West
Zucco v. Zucco, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 593 (2.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw. Zucco v. Zucco, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 593 (2012), as excerpted here, is not a family-law decision; it concerns enforcement of a mechanic’s lien and the ‘amount due or to become due’ under G.L. c. 254 in a construction-contract setting. It therefore does not address or establish any family-law principles and does not support a claim about citing relevant Massachusetts family law or family-law caselaw.
Zucco v. Zucco, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 593 (2.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 254, § 4, permits a subcontractor to file a notice of contract in the appropriate registry of deeds at any time after the execution of a written contract with the general contractor to perform labor or furnish materials… The statute is strictly construed against the party claiming the lien, and that includes establishing that money is due or to become due.”

Ross v. Ross, 385 Mass. 30 (1982).proposition: This Complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw, including but not limited to:
Ross v. Ross, 385 Mass. 30 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition is extremely general: that the complaint cites relevant Massachusetts family law and caselaw. Ross v. Ross is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court decision addressing core family-law issues—alimony, property division under G.L. c. 208, § 34, Rule 60(b) relief from judgments, separate support, arrears, and counsel fees. It squarely concerns Massachusetts divorce and support law, so using it as an example of relevant Massachusetts family-law caselaw is accurate.
Ross v. Ross, 385 Mass. 30 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 34, empowers the courts to make an equitable division of property incident to a divorce proceeding… The husband argues that the probate judge failed to comply with the requirements of § 34… We have carefully read the judge’s findings and hold that he did, in fact, adequately consider all the factors.”
